title: Cat. 87  The Terrace, Luxembourg, 1894
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 871894Way: 55  
Levy: 86  
Transfer lithograph with stumping, drawn on fine-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, center left  
One state; image size: 100 × 216 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 25  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 84, 87, 98, 99, 108, 135, 183, 260–64  
Posthumous edition: 51 impressions printed by Goulding on 25 April 1904  
Posthumous watermarks: 15, 50–53, 165, 211, 214, 219, 220, 270, 314  
Stone: erased in 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: 95, 96, 97, 99, 107; apps. II.3, II.4, III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Way and Dennis (1903), p. 86  
Lifetime Exhibitions: New York 1894; London 1895? (no. 93, as In the Gardens—Tuileries); London 1895–96 (no. 56); London 1898–99 (no. 1989); Chicago 1900b (no. 51); New York 1901 (no. 148)

Whistler mailed this “new and pet drawing of Terrace Luxembourg gardens” from Paris to his printers in London on about 19 July 1894, placing it in the middle of a package of Japanese paper (letter 95). It must have been one of four new drawings that the Ways transferred to stone and proved on July 21 (apps. II.3 and II.4). Throughout the month of July, Whistler had been hard at work on transfer drawings for lithographs and kept the printers busy as he sent new images for processing, along with letters of instruction, on an almost daily basis. His letters indicate that he was impatient for the Ways to print sets of twenty-five impressions of each of the new lithographs immediately upon his approval of the initial proofs.

Whistler produced four lithographs depicting the Luxembourg Gardens in late 1893 and early 1894 (cat. 68, cat.&nbsp;69, cat. 70, and cat. 81). Returning to the gardens in the summer of 1894, he provided a less elaborate background for the group of figures, although an unidentified building is faintly delineated in the background at upper right. The artist made more limited use of the stump than he had in the previous Luxembourg subjects, applying only slight touches in the foliage of the small tree and in the urn on the balustrade.

Chicago: AIC (2), cream laid Japanese vellum (193 × 339 mm), signed; cream laid Japanese vellum (198 × 335 mm), signed; MWC, ivory laid paper (190 × 242 mm), signed; Palmer, cream laid paper (198 × 331 mm); SC, cream laid paper (205 × 331 mm). Glasgow: HAG (6), ivory laid paper (190 × 241 mm), signed; cream laid paper (194 × 239 mm), signed; cream Japanese paper (202 × 278 mm), signed; cream laid Japanese vellum (193 × 330 mm), signed; ivory laid paper (333 × 201 mm); cream laid paper (207 × 313 mm). London: BM, cream wove Japanese vellum (216 × 292 mm). Washington: FGA, cream laid paper (194 × 242 mm), signed; LC cream laid Japanese vellum (185 × 337 mm), signed; NGA, cream laid paper (189 × 239 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Ann Arbor, UMMA; Brooklyn, TBM; Cambridge, Mass., FAM; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi
